sen.j: 仙洞御所 (せんとうごしょ)とは、退位した天皇（上皇・法皇）の御所。
sen.e: "Sento gosho" is the imperial palace of an abdicated emperor (retired emperor and cloistered emperor).
"Sento gosho" is the imperial palace of an abdicated emperor (retired or cloistered emperor).
"Sento gosho" is the imperial palace of an abdicated emperor (retired or cloistered emperor).

sen.j: 仙洞とは本来仙人の住み処をいい「せんどう」とも読まれる。
sen.e: Sento originally refers to the residence of mountain hermits and is also read as 'sendo.'
Sento originally refers to the residence of mountain hermits and is also read as 'sendo.'
Sento originally refers to the residence of mountain hermits and is also read as 'sendo.'

sen.j: そこから転じて退位した天皇（上皇・法皇）の御所をいい、さらに転じて上皇・法皇の異称としても使われた。
sen.e: This, in turn, came to mean the imperial palace of an abdicated emperor (retired emperor and cloistered emperor), and then was also used as a synonym for retired emperor and cloistered emperor.
This, in turn, came to mean the imperial palace of an abdicated emperor (retired emperor or cloistered emperor), it was then also used as a synonym for retired or a cloistered emperor.
This, in turn, came to mean the imperial palace of an abdicated emperor (retired emperor or cloistered emperor), it was then also used as a synonym for a retired or cloistered emperor.

sen.j: 仙人とは中国で古くから信じられた理想的な人間像で、俗世を離れて深山に隠遁することから、退位した天皇の住まいの美称として用いられるようになった。
sen.e: Mountain hermit is an idealized human figure, believed in China since ancient times, and because he lives secluded deep in the mountains, away from this world, it was used as a word praising the residence of abdicated emperors.

Mountain hermit is an idealized human figure, believed in China since ancient times, and because he lives secluded deep in the mountains, away from this world, it was used as a word praising the residence of abdicated emperors.

Mountain hermit is an idealized human figure, believed in China since ancient times, and because he lives secluded deep in the mountains, away from this world, it was used as a word praising the residence of abdicated emperors.

sen.j: 貴人の住まいを「御所」ということから「仙洞御所」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Since the residence of noblemen are called 'gosho,' it was called 'sento gosho.'
Since the residence of noblemen are called 'gosho,' it was called 'sento gosho.'
Since the residence of noblemen are called 'gosho,' it was called 'sento gosho.'

sen.j: 上皇・法皇は退位後、内裏から退去して仙洞御所に移るのを常とし、里内裏が多くそれにあてられた。
sen.e: Retired emperors and cloistered emperors typically retired from the dairi (inner palace) and moved to the sento gosho after being abdicated, and satodairi (dairi where emperors live) was often used for this purpose.

Retired and cloistered emperors typically retired from the dairi (inner palace) and moved to the sento gosho after abdicating, and the satodairi (dairi where emperors live) was often used for this purpose.

Retired and cloistered emperors typically retired from the dairi (Imperial Palace) and moved to the sento gosho after abdicating, and the satodairi (a temporary palace) was often used for this purpose.
sen.cmt: 内裏、里内裏の翻訳を変更

sen.j: 仙洞御所はまた「院（いん）」とも呼ばれ、これも上皇・法皇の別称として使われた。
sen.e: Sento gosho was also called 'in,' and this was also used as a synonym for retired emperor and cloistered emperor.
Sento gosho was also called 'in,' and this was also used as a synonym for retired and cloistered emperors.
Sento gosho was also called 'in,' and this was also used as a synonym for retired and cloistered emperors.

sen.j: 仙洞御所には家政機関としての院庁（いんのちょう）が置かれたほか、白河天皇の時には近衛として「北面の武士」のちに「西面の武士」が設置された。
sen.e: At the sento gosho, innocho, an agency for the household, was placed, as well as 'Hokumen no bushi (North-facing soldiers) and later, Saimen no bushi (West-facing soldiers), as imperial guards for Emperor Shirakawa.

At the sento gosho, innocho, an agency for the household, was placed, as well as 'Hokumen no bushi (North-facing soldiers) and later, Saimen no bushi (West-facing soldiers), as imperial guards for Emperor Shirakawa.

At the sento gosho, innocho (Retired Emperor's Office), an agency for the household, was placed, as well as 'Hokumen no bushi (the Imperial Palace Guards for the north side) and later, Saimen no bushi (the Imperial Palace Guards for the west side), as imperial guards for Emperor Shirakawa.
sen.cmt: 院庁の説明補足「北面の武士」、「西面の武士」の訳を変更

tit.e: Sento gosho at the Kyoto Imperial Garden
Sento gosho at the Kyoto Imperial Garden

sen.j: 現在、京都市にある京都御苑内には京都御所の南東に仙洞御所が位置している。
sen.e: Today, in the Kyoto Imperial Garden in Kyoto City, sento gosho is located southeast of the Kyoto Imperial Palace,
Today, in the Kyoto Imperial Garden in Kyoto City, sento gosho is located southeast of the Kyoto Imperial Palace,
Today, in the Kyoto Imperial Garden in Kyoto City, sento gosho is located southeast of the Kyoto Imperial Palace,

sen.j: これは1627年（寛永4）に後水尾天皇のために造営されたもので、正式名称は桜町殿という。
sen.e: This was built in 1627 for Emperor Gomizunoo, and its official name is Sakuramachiden.
This was built in 1627 for Emperor Gomizunoo, and its official name is Sakuramachiden.
This was built in 1627 for Emperor Gomizunoo, and its official name is Sakuramachiden.

sen.j: 小堀遠州によって作事された庭園が広がっている。
sen.e: A garden landscaped by Enshu KOBORI stretches.
A garden landscaped by Enshu KOBORI stretches.
A garden landscaped by Enshu KOBORI stretches.

sen.j: 仙洞御所の建築群は1854年（安政1）の火災後再建されず、現在では庭園のみが残っている。
sen.e: The buildings of the sento gosho were not rebuilt after the fire in 1854, and only the garden remains today.
The buildings of the sento gosho were not rebuilt after the fire in 1854, and only the garden remains today.
The buildings of the sento gosho were not rebuilt after the fire in 1854, and only the garden remains today.

sen.j: なお、仙洞御所東北に隣接する大宮御所は後水尾天皇の中宮であった東福門院の女院御所として造営されたものが元となっている。
sen.e: The Omiya gosho lying northeast of the sento gosho was originally built as the nyoin gosho (imperial palace of close female relatives of the emperor or a woman of comparable standing) for Tofukumonin, who was the chugu (wife of an emperor) of Emperor Gomizunoo.

The Omiya gosho lying northeast of the sento gosho was originally built as the nyoin gosho (imperial palace of close female relatives of the emperor or a woman of comparable standing) for Tofukumonin, who was the chugu (wife of an emperor) of Emperor Gomizunoo.

The Omiya gosho lying northeast of the sento gosho was originally built as the nyoin gosho (imperial palace of close female relatives of the emperor or a woman of comparable standing) for Tofukumonin, who was the chugu (wife of an emperor) of Emperor Gomizunoo.
